topics.title: The LumiÃ¨re Brothers and the First Films

hook.text: In 1895, a Paris audience screamed as a train appeared to rush toward them. It was a projected film.

buildup.text: Auguste and Louis LumiÃ¨re invented the CinÃ©matographe â€” a camera, projector, and printer in one device.

discovery.text: Their first films were simple: workers leaving a factory, a baby eating, a train arriving at a station.

twist.text: They thought cinema was 'an invention without a future.' Within a decade, it was the world's top entertainment.

climax.text: Their 50-second films launched an industry worth hundreds of billions. From curiosity to culture.

punchline.text: Cinema started as a science demo. It became humanity's mirror.

quiz.question: What did the LumiÃ¨re Brothers invent?
options: The CinÃ©matographe â€” a combined camera, projector, and printer
The first color film
The first sound recording device

topics.title: Georges MÃ©liÃ¨s: The First Visual Effects Artist

hook.text: A rocket crashes into the Moon's eye. That iconic 1902 image was cinema's first special effect.

buildup.text: MÃ©liÃ¨s was a stage magician who saw film as a new kind of illusion. He built sets, costumes, and tricks.

discovery.text: He invented dissolves, multiple exposures, and hand-painted color frames â€” all before 1910.

twist.text: He went bankrupt as studios industrialized filmmaking. His films were melted down for boot-heel chemicals.

climax.text: Rediscovered decades later, he's now honored as the father of science fiction and fantasy cinema.

punchline.text: Every Marvel movie owes a debt to a French magician from 1902.

quiz.question: What was Georges MÃ©liÃ¨s' famous 1902 film?
options: A Trip to the Moon â€” featuring a rocket hitting the Moon's eye
The Great Train Robbery
Nosferatu

topics.title: Silent Film Era: Acting Without Words

hook.text: Charlie Chaplin's Tramp didn't speak a word but made millions laugh and cry. Pure visual storytelling.

buildup.text: Silent films relied on exaggerated gestures, facial expressions, and intertitle cards for dialogue.

discovery.text: Without sound, filmmakers perfected visual grammar: close-ups for emotion, wide shots for context.

twist.text: Many silent-era techniques vanished when sound arrived. Directors had to relearn filmmaking from scratch.

climax.text: Buster Keaton performed stunts that still terrify audiences. No wires, no CGI, no safety nets.

punchline.text: The silent era proved: cinema is a visual medium first.

quiz.question: Why did silent films develop strong visual storytelling?
options: Without sound, every emotion had to be communicated visually
Audiences couldn't read intertitle cards
Cameras couldn't focus properly

topics.title: The Talkies: Cinema Gets a Voice

hook.text: 'Wait a minute, you ain't heard nothin' yet!' Al Jolson's line in 1927 ended the silent era forever.

buildup.text: The Jazz Singer was the first feature with synchronized dialogue. Audiences were electrified.

discovery.text: Sound added realism but killed careers. Many silent stars had voices that didn't match their image.

twist.text: Early sound cameras were trapped in soundproof booths. Films became static and stage-like for years.

climax.text: Engineers freed the camera with boom microphones and post-dubbing. Cinema became dynamic again by the 1930s.

punchline.text: Sound didn't just add dialogue. It reinvented the entire art form.

quiz.question: What was the first feature film with synchronized dialogue?
options: The Jazz Singer (1927)
Citizen Kane (1941)
Gone with the Wind (1939)

topics.title: Montage: Editing as Storytelling

hook.text: Rocky punches meat, runs stairs, does push-ups â€” all in 60 seconds. That's a training montage.

buildup.text: Montage compresses time by cutting together a series of shots to show progression or parallel events.

discovery.text: Soviet filmmaker Eisenstein proved that the meaning of a shot changes based on what shot follows it.

twist.text: Show a face, then food: the man looks hungry. Same face, then a coffin: he looks sad. Same face, different story.

climax.text: The Kuleshov Effect proved that audiences create meaning from juxtaposition, not just from images alone.

punchline.text: Cinema isn't in the shots. It's in the cuts between them.

quiz.question: What does the Kuleshov Effect demonstrate?
options: Audiences create meaning from the juxtaposition of shots
Longer shots are more emotional
Color affects mood in film

topics.title: Camera Movements: Tracking, Panning, and Dolly Shots

hook.text: The Steadicam following Danny on his tricycle through the Overlook Hotel. Camera movement creates dread.

buildup.text: A pan rotates the camera. A tilt looks up or down. A dolly moves the camera physically through space.

discovery.text: Tracking shots follow a character, creating intimacy. Static shots create distance and observation.

twist.text: The 'dolly zoom' (Vertigo effect) changes focal length while moving the camera, warping perspective eerily.

climax.text: Kubrick, Scorsese, and Spielberg are masters of camera movement. Each move is a narrative choice.

punchline.text: When the camera moves, the audience feels it. Physically.

quiz.question: What is a dolly zoom (Vertigo effect)?
options: Changing focal length while moving the camera to warp perspective
A fast spinning camera movement
Zooming in during a slow-motion shot

topics.title: Color Grading: How Color Sets the Mood

hook.text: The Matrix is green-tinted inside the simulation. The real world is cold blue. Color tells you where you are.

buildup.text: Color grading is the process of adjusting colors in post-production to create a specific visual mood.

discovery.text: Warm tones (orange, yellow) suggest nostalgia, comfort. Cool tones (blue, teal) suggest isolation, tension.

twist.text: Hollywood's most common grade: teal and orange. It makes skin tones pop against cool backgrounds.

climax.text: Wes Anderson uses candy colors for whimsy. David Fincher uses desaturated palettes for grit. Style is color.

punchline.text: A film's color palette is its emotional fingerprint.

quiz.question: Why does Hollywood frequently use the teal-and-orange color grade?
options: It makes warm skin tones pop against cool backgrounds
Those colors are cheapest to produce digitally
Audiences subconsciously prefer those two colors

topics.title: Shot Composition: Close-Ups to Wide Shots

hook.text: A close-up of a ticking clock. Cut to a wide shot of an empty room. The shot size changes the tension.

buildup.text: Wide shots establish location. Medium shots show interaction. Close-ups reveal emotion and detail.

discovery.text: The extreme close-up â€” just the eyes â€” creates maximum intensity. Sergio Leone made it his signature.

twist.text: A close-up in a wide room feels intimate. A wide shot in a tiny space feels claustrophobic. Context is everything.

climax.text: Directors plan shot sequences: wide to establish, medium to develop, close-up for the emotional peak.

punchline.text: Shot size isn't a technical choice. It's an emotional instruction.

quiz.question: What is the primary purpose of a close-up shot in film?
options: To reveal emotion and intimate detail
To show the full location
To display action sequences clearly

topics.title: Film Noir: Shadows and Moral Ambiguity

hook.text: Rain-slicked streets. Venetian blind shadows across a detective's face. A femme fatale walks in. Film noir.

buildup.text: Film noir emerged in 1940s Hollywood: crime dramas with cynical heroes, moral ambiguity, and dark visuals.

discovery.text: Its visual style â€” low-key lighting, extreme shadows, tilted angles â€” was borrowed from German Expressionism.

twist.text: French critics named it 'film noir' (dark cinema) in 1946. The filmmakers themselves didn't use the term.

climax.text: Blade Runner, Sin City, and Chinatown all carry noir DNA. The genre never died â€” it evolved.

punchline.text: In noir, the shadows aren't just on the walls. They're in the characters.

quiz.question: Where did film noir borrow its visual style from?
options: German Expressionism â€” using shadows, low-key lighting, and tilted angles
Italian Neorealism â€” using natural light and real locations
French New Wave â€” using handheld cameras and jump cuts

topics.title: Italian Neorealism: Cinema of the Streets

hook.text: A man and his son search Rome for a stolen bicycle. It's heartbreaking, unglamorous, and entirely real.

buildup.text: Italian Neorealism (1940s-50s) rejected studio sets for real locations and non-professional actors.

discovery.text: Born from post-war poverty, filmmakers couldn't afford studios. Limitation became artistic philosophy.

twist.text: Hollywood told fantasy. Neorealism showed workers, poverty, and daily survival. It shocked global audiences.

climax.text: De Sica, Rossellini, and Visconti inspired every independent film movement that followed.

punchline.text: Neorealism proved that reality is more dramatic than fiction.

quiz.question: What defined Italian Neorealism?
options: Real locations, non-professional actors, and stories of ordinary life
Elaborate studio sets and professional actors
Science fiction themes and special effects

topics.title: French New Wave: Breaking Every Rule

hook.text: Jean-Luc Godard's jump cuts in Breathless shocked critics. He'd cut mid-sentence, mid-action. On purpose.

buildup.text: The French New Wave (late 1950s) was led by young critics who became directors: Godard, Truffaut, Varda.

discovery.text: They shot on streets with handheld cameras, improvised dialogue, and broke the fourth wall.

twist.text: They wrote about cinema before making it. Their criticism shaped their filmmaking philosophy.

climax.text: New Wave's influence is everywhere: Tarantino, Wes Anderson, and modern indie cinema all carry its DNA.

punchline.text: They proved that the rules of cinema exist so someone can break them.

quiz.question: What was a signature technique of French New Wave filmmakers?
options: Jump cuts, handheld cameras, and breaking the fourth wall
Perfect continuity editing and studio lighting
Only shooting in black and white

topics.title: The Horror Genre: Why We Love Being Scared

hook.text: You know the monster is behind the door. The music swells. Your heart races. You love every second.

buildup.text: Horror cinema works by triggering the fight-or-flight response safely. Real fear, zero real danger.

discovery.text: Suspense (knowing something the character doesn't) is scarier than surprise (sudden jump scares).

twist.text: The scariest horror films often show very little. Jaws barely shows the shark. Your imagination fills the gap.

climax.text: Horror reflects societal fears: nuclear anxiety (1950s monsters), technology (modern), pandemics, isolation.

punchline.text: Horror doesn't exploit fear. It helps us rehearse it safely.

quiz.question: Why did Jaws show the shark so rarely?
options: Showing less forces the audience's imagination to create scarier imagery
The mechanical shark kept breaking down (happy accident)
Audiences complained about the shark's appearance

topics.title: The Role of Sound Design in Film

hook.text: In Saving Private Ryan's beach scene, the sound cuts to muffled ringing. You experience the soldier's shell shock.

buildup.text: Sound design includes dialogue, ambient noise, foley effects, and silence. Each is a storytelling tool.

discovery.text: Foley artists recreate sounds manually: footsteps on gravel, doors creaking, clothes rustling. All performed live.

twist.text: Strategic silence is the most powerful sound effect. Remove all sound, and the audience leans in with tension.

climax.text: Ben Burtt created the Star Wars lightsaber hum from a TV set and a film projector motor. Pure creativity.

punchline.text: You watch a film with your eyes. You feel it with your ears.

quiz.question: What is foley in sound design?
options: Manually recreating everyday sounds (footsteps, doors) for film
Adding digital music to scenes
Recording dialogue in a studio

topics.title: Film Scores: Music That Moves You

hook.text: Two notes: duh-DUN, duh-DUN. You already see a shark fin. John Williams made Jaws unforgettable with music.

buildup.text: A film score is the original music composed specifically for a movie, played under scenes to guide emotion.

discovery.text: Scores tell you how to feel: swelling strings for triumph, minor keys for sadness, dissonance for unease.

twist.text: Watch any dramatic scene on mute. Without the score, the emotion drops by half. Music is invisible power.

climax.text: Hans Zimmer's Inception horn, Ennio Morricone's whistled westerns, Howard Shore's Shire theme â€” all iconic.

punchline.text: A great score doesn't accompany the scene. It becomes the scene.

quiz.question: What role does a film score play in storytelling?
options: It guides the audience's emotional response to scenes
It replaces the need for dialogue
It is only used during opening credits

topics.title: Leitmotifs: Musical Themes for Characters

hook.text: Every time Darth Vader appears, the Imperial March plays. That recurring theme is called a leitmotif.

buildup.text: A leitmotif is a short musical phrase associated with a character, place, or idea. Wagner pioneered it in opera.

discovery.text: In Lord of the Rings, each culture has its own theme. The Shire is warm; Mordor is industrial and harsh.

twist.text: Leitmotifs can be transformed: major key becomes minor, fast becomes slow. The theme evolves with the character.

climax.text: John Williams used over 50 leitmotifs across the Star Wars saga. Each one is instantly recognizable.

punchline.text: You don't just see a character arrive. You hear them coming.

quiz.question: What is a leitmotif in film music?
options: A recurring musical theme associated with a character, place, or idea
The opening song of a film
Background noise used for realism

topics.title: Diegetic vs. Non-Diegetic Sound

hook.text: A character turns on a radio and music plays. That's diegetic. The dramatic score underneath is not.

buildup.text: Diegetic sound exists within the story world: dialogue, car horns, a phone ringing. Characters can hear it.

discovery.text: Non-diegetic sound is added for the audience only: narration, score, sound effects. Characters are unaware.

twist.text: Edgar Wright blurs the line: in Baby Driver, car chases are choreographed to the character's earbuds playlist.

climax.text: Breaking diegesis â€” when a score suddenly becomes a source sound or vice versa â€” creates surprise.

punchline.text: Half the sounds in any film don't exist inside the story.

quiz.question: What is diegetic sound in film?
options: Sound that exists within the story world and characters can hear
Background music added for the audience only
Sound effects created in post-production

topics.title: Alfred Hitchcock: The Master of Suspense

hook.text: Hitchcock showed a bomb under a table. The characters don't know. The audience does. That's pure suspense.

buildup.text: Alfred Hitchcock directed over 50 films spanning silent cinema to the 1970s. Each one is a masterclass in tension.

discovery.text: He storyboarded every frame obsessively. By the time he shot, the film was already 'finished' in his mind.

twist.text: Psycho's shower scene has 70 camera angles in 45 seconds. It's violent yet shows almost nothing graphic.

climax.text: Rear Window, Vertigo, North by Northwest â€” his films defined thriller conventions still used today.

punchline.text: Hitchcock didn't show you what to fear. He made you imagine it.

quiz.question: How did Hitchcock create suspense according to his own philosophy?
options: By letting the audience know more than the characters on screen
By using sudden jump scares
By filming only in dark environments

topics.title: Stanley Kubrick: Obsessive Perfectionist

hook.text: Kubrick made Shelley Duvall film the baseball bat scene in The Shining 127 times. Take after take after take.

buildup.text: Stanley Kubrick controlled every detail: lighting, set design, music, lenses, even the color of props.

discovery.text: His symmetrical compositions and one-point perspective shots create beauty that feels unsettling.

twist.text: He genre-hopped: war (Full Metal Jacket), sci-fi (2001), horror (The Shining), period drama (Barry Lyndon).

climax.text: Barry Lyndon was lit entirely by candlelight using a NASA lens. No other filmmaker would attempt it.

punchline.text: Kubrick didn't make films for his time. He made them for all time.

quiz.question: What lens did Kubrick use to film Barry Lyndon by candlelight?
options: A special NASA lens designed for satellite photography
A standard cinema lens with high ISO film
A custom German lens made for submarines

topics.title: Akira Kurosawa: Japan's Gift to World Cinema

hook.text: A wandering samurai plays two gangs against each other.

buildup.text: Kurosawa pioneered the 'wipe' transition, multi-camera setups, and weather as a dramatic element.

discovery.text: Seven Samurai (1954) created the 'assemble a team' template used by everything from The Magnificent Seven to Avengers.

twist.text: George Lucas modeled Star Wars directly on Kurosawa's The Hidden Fortress.

climax.text: His use of movement â€” rain, wind, running horses â€” made action cinema visceral and emotional.

punchline.text: Every blockbuster action film is standing on Kurosawa's shoulders.

quiz.question: Which Kurosawa film directly inspired Star Wars?
options: The Hidden Fortress â€” its two peasant characters became R2-D2 and C-3PO
Seven Samurai â€” its team assembly inspired the Rebel Alliance
Rashomon â€” its multiple perspectives inspired the Force

topics.title: CGI: From Jurassic Park to Everything

hook.text: When the T. Rex appeared in Jurassic Park (1993), audiences gasped. CGI dinosaurs looked completely real.

buildup.text: Computer-Generated Imagery (CGI) creates visual elements digitally that would be impossible or too dangerous to film.

discovery.text: Spielberg used CGI for only 6 minutes of Jurassic Park. The rest was practical effects and clever editing.

twist.text: Bad CGI ages terribly. Good CGI is invisible â€” you don't even realize you're looking at it.

climax.text: Films like Avatar and Planet of the Apes show CGI can create emotion, not just spectacle.

punchline.text: The best CGI is the CGI you don't notice.

quiz.question: How much CGI did Jurassic Park actually use for dinosaurs?
options: Only about 6 minutes â€” the rest was practical effects
The entire film was CGI
About half the dinosaur scenes

topics.title: Streaming Wars: How Distribution Changed Cinema

hook.text: Netflix spent $17 billion on content in a single year. More than most countries' entire film industries combined.

buildup.text: Streaming platforms disrupted the theatrical release model. Films now premiere on screens in your pocket.

discovery.text: The window between theater and home release shrank from months to days. Some films skip theaters entirely.

twist.text: Scorsese called Marvel films 'not cinema.' The debate about what counts as cinema intensified.

climax.text: International films found global audiences through streaming. Parasite's Oscar win was partly a streaming effect.

punchline.text: Cinema isn't dying. It's moving to a different screen.

quiz.question: How has streaming changed international cinema?
options: International films found global audiences they couldn't reach through theaters alone
International films lost all audiences
Only Hollywood films are available on streaming

topics.title: Animation: Not Just for Kids

hook.text: In the first 10 minutes of Up, Pixar made adults cry harder than most live-action dramas manage in two hours.

buildup.text: Animation began with hand-drawn cells, evolved to stop-motion, and now includes 3D CGI and hybrid styles.

discovery.text: Studio Ghibli's films tackle war, environmentalism, and grief. Anime proved animation has no age ceiling.

twist.text: Spider-Verse combined CGI with comic-book printing styles, reinventing what animation looks like.

climax.text: Animation's creative freedom lets filmmakers visualize the impossible: feelings, dreams, abstract concepts.

punchline.text: Animation isn't a genre. It's a medium without limits.

quiz.question: Why is animation considered a medium rather than a genre?
options: It can tell any type of story â€” not limited to children's content
It always uses the same visual style
It can only be produced by large studios

topics.title: The Auteur Theory: Director as Author

hook.text: You can tell a Wes Anderson film in 3 seconds: centered frames, pastel palettes, deadpan delivery.

buildup.text: Auteur theory argues that the director is the primary creative author of a film, like a novelist of a book.

discovery.text: French critic AndrÃ© Bazin and the Cahiers du cinÃ©ma group championed this idea in the 1950s.

twist.text: Critics argue filmmaking is collaborative. Editors, cinematographers, and writers shape films equally.

climax.text: Despite debate, auteur-driven films often have the strongest artistic identity: Kubrick, Lynch, Villeneuve.

punchline.text: An auteur doesn't just make films. They make a world.

quiz.question: What does auteur theory argue?
options: The director is the primary creative author of a film
Films should be made without a director
Actors control the creative vision

topics.title: The Three-Act Structure in Screenwriting

hook.text: Boy meets girl (Act 1). Boy loses girl (Act 2). Boy wins girl back (Act 3). Every romcom. Every time.

buildup.text: The three-act structure divides a story into setup, confrontation, and resolution. It's cinema's backbone.

discovery.text: Act 1 hooks you (first 25%). Act 2 tests the hero with escalating obstacles (next 50%). Act 3 resolves it (final 25%).

twist.text: Some filmmakers reject it entirely. Pulp Fiction scrambles chronology. Memento runs backwards.

climax.text: The structure works because it mirrors how humans process stories: question, struggle, answer.

punchline.text: Three acts aren't a formula. They're how brains expect stories to unfold.

quiz.question: What are the three acts in traditional screenwriting structure?
options: Setup, confrontation, and resolution
Introduction, flashback, and epilogue
Dialogue, action, and credits

topics.title: World Cinema: Stories Beyond Hollywood

hook.text: Parasite won Best Picture at the Oscars. A Korean film. In Korean. Hollywood's wall cracked open.

buildup.text: World cinema encompasses every national film tradition outside Hollywood: Indian, Nigerian, Iranian, Korean.

discovery.text: Bollywood produces over 1,500 films per year â€” more than Hollywood. Nollywood in Nigeria isn't far behind.

twist.text: Many acclaimed 'Hollywood' techniques originated abroad: jump cuts (France), long takes (Hungary), handheld (Denmark).

climax.text: Streaming gave global cinema direct access to worldwide audiences. Subtitles are no longer a barrier.

punchline.text: The best film in the world might not be in your language. Watch it anyway.

quiz.question: Which country produces more films per year than Hollywood?
options: India (Bollywood) produces over 1,500 films annually
Nigeria (Nollywood) produces over 3,000 films
Both India and Nigeria outpace Hollywood

topics.title: Film Festivals: Cannes, Venice, and Sundance

hook.text: The Palme d'Or at Cannes is cinema's most prestigious award. Winning it can define a director's entire career.

buildup.text: Film festivals premiere new work, connect filmmakers with distributors, and set critical consensus.

discovery.text: Cannes (est. 1946) champions art cinema. Sundance (est. 1978) launches independent films. Venice is the oldest (1932).

twist.text: Many blockbusters skip festivals entirely. Festivals and box office success often reward completely different films.

climax.text: Sex, Lies, and Videotape (Sundance), Pulp Fiction (Cannes), and Brokeback Mountain (Venice) all launched at festivals.

punchline.text: Festivals don't predict box office. They predict cinema history.

quiz.question: What is the world's oldest film festival?
options: Venice Film Festival, established in 1932
Cannes Film Festival, established in 1946
Sundance Film Festival, established in 1978

topics.title: Cinematography: Painting With Light

hook.text: Roger Deakins lit a war scene in 1917 to look like one continuous shot at golden hour. It took months of planning.

buildup.text: Cinematography is the art of capturing images on camera: framing, movement, lens choice, and lighting.

discovery.text: The cinematographer (DP) translates the director's vision into visual language. Every shadow is intentional.

twist.text: Digital cameras changed the craft. DPs can now monitor color and exposure in real time, not after development.

climax.text: The best cinematography serves the story invisibly. You feel the mood without knowing why.

punchline.text: Cinematography is writing with light, shadow, and movement.

quiz.question: What does a cinematographer (DP) do?
options: Translates the director's vision into visual images through camera and light
Writes the screenplay
Edits the final cut of the film

topics.title: Method Acting: Becoming the Character

hook.text: Daniel Day-Lewis stayed in a wheelchair for months while filming My Left Foot. He refused to break character.

buildup.text: Method acting derives from Stanislavski's system: actors draw on personal emotions to inhabit a role fully.

discovery.text: Lee Strasberg brought it to America. Brando, De Niro, and Pacino all trained at his Actors Studio.

twist.text: Critics say Method acting can be self-indulgent and difficult for co-stars. Jared Leto's Joker gifts became infamous.

climax.text: Not all great actors use Method. Meryl Streep, Anthony Hopkins, and Cate Blanchett achieve depth differently.

punchline.text: Method acting isn't the only path to truth. It's just the most dramatic one.

quiz.question: What is Method acting based on?
options: Stanislavski's system of drawing on personal emotions to inhabit roles
Memorizing lines through repetition only
Improvising every scene without a script

topics.title: Film Festivals: Where Art Meets Industry

hook.text: The Palme d'Or at Cannes can turn an unknown filmmaker into a legend overnight. Festivals are cinema's kingmakers.

buildup.text: Film festivals serve as marketplaces where distributors buy films, critics build hype, and careers are launched.

discovery.text: The Big Three â€” Cannes, Venice, Berlin â€” each have a personality. Cannes is glamour, Venice is art, Berlin is politics.

twist.text: Sundance was created because Hollywood ignored independent voices. Now Hollywood scouts Sundance for its next franchise.

climax.text: Parasite won the Palme d'Or at Cannes in 2019, then swept the Oscars â€” the first non-English film to win Best Picture.

punchline.text: Festivals don't just screen films. They decide which films matter.

quiz.question: Why are film festivals important to the industry?
options: They serve as marketplaces for distribution deals and launch careers
They are primarily tourist attractions for host cities
They only screen films that already have distribution

topics.title: The Evolution of Special Effects

hook.text: In 1902, Georges MÃ©liÃ¨s made a rocket hit the Moon's eye using cardboard. A century later, Thanos felt real.

buildup.text: Special effects evolved from practical tricks â€” miniatures, matte paintings, stop-motion â€” to digital CGI worlds.

discovery.text: Jurassic Park (1993) was the turning point: animatronics plus CGI proved digital creatures could feel alive.

twist.text: More CGI doesn't mean better films. Mad Max: Fury Road (2015) used mostly practical stunts and won six Oscars.

climax.text: The Volume, LED walls used in The Mandalorian, merges practical and digital. Actors perform inside real-time CGI worlds.

punchline.text: The best effects are the ones you never notice.

quiz.question: What made Jurassic Park a turning point in special effects?
options: It proved digital CGI creatures could look convincingly real alongside practical effects
It was the first film to use any computer graphics
It eliminated the need for practical effects entirely
